body:
Hi, 
So I had the same "issue" a while ago. Technically, this is not an issue, though, because the plots from plotting.py are not intended to be there after training, but for you to watch during training. For saving plots after training, there is the code in visualization.py. However, not all plots you can find in plotting.py are also in visualization.py. Since I also wanted to save the plots from plotting.py to look at after training, I modified the code the following way:
I wrote the following function into plotting.py:
```
def save_plot(
    fig: Figure,
    directory: str,
    name: str,
    n: int
):
    file = directory + '/' + name + str(n)
    fig.savefig(file)
```
which saves the figures to a specified directory, and then modified the plotting methods, making them return figures, e.g. for spikes and weights that would be:
```
def plot_spikes(
    spikes: Dict[str, torch.Tensor],
    time: Optional[Tuple[int, int]] = None,
    n_neurons: Optional[Dict[str, Tuple[int, int]]] = None,
    ims: Optional[List[PathCollection]] = None,
    axes: Optional[Union[Axes, List[Axes]]] = None,
    figsize: Tuple[float, float] = (8.0, 4.5),
    fig: Figure = None
) -> Tuple[List[AxesImage], List[Axes], Figure]:
    # language=rst
    """
    Plot spikes for any group(s) of neurons.

    :param spikes: Mapping from layer names to spiking data. Spike data has shape
        ``[time, n_1, ..., n_k]``, where ``[n_1, ..., n_k]`` is the shape of the
        recorded layer.
    :param time: Plot spiking activity of neurons in the given time range. Default is
        entire simulation time.
    :param n_neurons: Plot spiking activity of neurons in the given range of neurons.
        Default is all neurons.
    :param ims: Used for re-drawing the plots.
    :param axes: Used for re-drawing the plots.
    :param figsize: Horizontal, vertical figure size in inches.
    :return: ``ims, axes``: Used for re-drawing the plots.
    """
    n_subplots = len(spikes.keys())
    if n_neurons is None:
        n_neurons = {}

    spikes = {k: v.view(v.size(0), -1) for (k, v) in spikes.items()}
    if time is None:
        # Set it for entire duration
        for key in spikes.keys():
            time = (0, spikes[key].shape[0])
            break

    # Use all neurons if no argument provided.
    for key, val in spikes.items():
        if key not in n_neurons.keys():
            n_neurons[key] = (0, val.shape[1])

    if ims is None:
        fig, axes = plt.subplots(n_subplots, 1, figsize=figsize)
        if n_subplots == 1:
            axes = [axes]

        ims = []
        for i, datum in enumerate(spikes.items()):
            spikes = (
                datum[1][
                    time[0] : time[1], n_neurons[datum[0]][0] : n_neurons[datum[0]][1]
                ]
                .detach()
                .clone()
                .cpu()
                .numpy()
            )
            ims.append(
                axes[i].scatter(
                    x=np.array(spikes.nonzero()).T[:, 0],
                    y=np.array(spikes.nonzero()).T[:, 1],
                    s=1,
                )
            )
            args = (
                datum[0],
                n_neurons[datum[0]][0],
                n_neurons[datum[0]][1],
                time[0],
                time[1],
            )
            axes[i].set_title(
                "%s spikes for neurons (%d - %d) from t = %d to %d " % args
            )
        for ax in axes:
            ax.set_aspect("auto")

        plt.setp(
            axes, xticks=[], yticks=[], xlabel="Simulation time", ylabel="Neuron index"
        )
        plt.tight_layout()
    else:
        for i, datum in enumerate(spikes.items()):
            spikes = (
                datum[1][
                    time[0] : time[1], n_neurons[datum[0]][0] : n_neurons[datum[0]][1]
                ]
                .detach()
                .clone()
                .cpu()
                .numpy()
            )
            ims[i].set_offsets(np.array(spikes.nonzero()).T)
            args = (
                datum[0],
                n_neurons[datum[0]][0],
                n_neurons[datum[0]][1],
                time[0],
                time[1],
            )
            axes[i].set_title(
                "%s spikes for neurons (%d - %d) from t = %d to %d " % args
            )

    plt.draw()

    return ims, axes, fig


def plot_weights(
    weights: torch.Tensor,
    wmin: Optional[float] = 0,
    wmax: Optional[float] = 1,
    im: Optional[AxesImage] = None,
    figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (5, 5),
    cmap: str = "hot_r",
    fig: Figure = None
) -> Tuple[AxesImage, Figure]:
    # language=rst
    """
    Plot a connection weight matrix.

    :param weights: Weight matrix of ``Connection`` object.
    :param wmin: Minimum allowed weight value.
    :param wmax: Maximum allowed weight value.
    :param im: Used for re-drawing the weights plot.
    :param figsize: Horizontal, vertical figure size in inches.
    :param cmap: Matplotlib colormap.
    :return: ``AxesImage`` for re-drawing the weights plot.
    """
    local_weights = weights.detach().clone().cpu().numpy()
    if not im:
        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=figsize)

        im = ax.imshow(local_weights, cmap=cmap, vmin=wmin, vmax=wmax)
        div = make_axes_locatable(ax)
        cax = div.append_axes("right", size="5%", pad=0.05)

        ax.set_xticks(())
        ax.set_yticks(())
        ax.set_aspect("auto")

        plt.colorbar(im, cax=cax)
        fig.tight_layout()
    else:
        im.set_data(local_weights)

    return im, fig
```
and then I called them in my main program – to which I passed a directory to save the plots in as a command line argument – the following way:
```
spike_ims, spike_axes, spike_fig = plot_spikes(
            {layer: spikes[layer].get("s").view(time, 1, -1) for layer in spikes},
            ims=spike_ims,
            axes=spike_axes,
            fig=spike_fig
        )
  save_plot(fig=spike_fig, directory=directory, name="spikes", n=i)
  weights_im, weights_fig = plot_weights(square_weights, im=weights_im, fig=weights_fig)
  save_plot(fig=weights_fig, directory=directory, name="weights", n=i)
```
Maybe you could do it a similar way, I hope this helps...
P.S. I'm not one of the scientists developing the BindsNET library, this is just "peer-to-peer" help ;)
Thank you very much for your help.

Mam ,the above save plot is giving error like this:
![save_plot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38427571/81559837-21a00200-93cb-11ea-9834-68b15f54f68f.PNG)

Oh, I guess I forgot to mention the import statement:
`from matplotlib.figure import Figure`

Yeah it's working.
Mam, below every plot function, I have to call fig :Figure =None??

That's nice to hear :)
I'm not sure whether you need fig :Figure =None . How about you just try it out by running a small example with or without? Then you'll see what works and what doesn't...

Mam, didn't get any plot.
This is my code:

wrote:

I can't see your code, it just says "..." and then shows part of an E-Mail ... Could you post it again?
Also: I thought you said earlier that it worked?

Anyways: Did you provide a directory path at the appropriate point(s) in the code? (e.g. I included a command line argument for it that I then write to the variable "directory" in my code...) If not, that might be the problem because that would be the place where the plots are saved (as .png-files)...

This is what i plotted but plot didn't save:
![plotting](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38427571/81580269-30e17880-93e8-11ea-95fc-6caf615bf454.PNG)

So first of all: Have you modified the code in plotting.py to return the figures (because usually, it just returns the axes and ims, not fig)? (And did you import Figure there, too, doing so?)
If that works correctly, I'm not sure where your problem is either, I'm sorry.
I think the way you specified your directory (without *.png) should be fine, by the way ...

Anyway, if you're interested, you can find my modified code in its entirety at:
- https://github.com/Danielle-Schuman/bindsnetQA/blob/master/examples/mnist/supervised_mnist.py (This is my "main", where I modified supervised_mnist.py)
and 
- https://github.com/Danielle-Schuman/bindsnetQA/blob/master/bindsnet_qa/analysis/plotting.py (Here the modified plotting.py. I did not modify all plotting methods, e.g. not plot_conv2d_weights, only the ones I needed for my project, i.e. the ones I call in the module in the first link)
(By the way: My project is all about trying out a different way of calculating in network.run(...), so that's different, too, there, but that doesn't impact the plotting, since the outputs are the same. So just ignore that part.)

I wish you good luck!

Thank you very much.
